chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess an adult with tiredness/fatigue?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If an adult presents with tiredness/fatigue:

  • Ask about:
    • What the person means by tiredness or fatigue.
      • Sleepiness may indicate sleep apnoea or another sleep disorder. See the CKS topics on Obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome and Insomnia for more information.
      • Weakness may suggest a neuromuscular cause.
    • The onset, duration, severity, and precipitating factors.
      • Onset is typically sudden with infection, toxins or drugs, and post-traumatic stress.
      • Onset is usually gradual in uraemia, heart failure, liver failure, diabetes mellitus, hypercalcaemia, hypothyroidism, electrolyte abnormalities, anaemia, and depression.
      • Persistent fatigue that is worse in the morning may suggest depression.
    • The effect of sleep, rest, and exercise on symptoms, and the impact on daily activities.
    • Sleep quality, quantity, patterns, sleep hygiene measures, snoring, witnessed sleep apnoea, nocturia, and restless legs. See the CKS topics on Insomnia, Obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome, and Restless legs syndrome for more information.
    • Any stress or stressful life events, work and shifts, quality of personal relationships, any dependents and carer stress, any domestic abuse, recreational drug use, usual diet, and alcohol consumption.
    • Housing situation and possibility of carbon monoxide poisoning. See the CKS topic on Carbon monoxide poisoning for more information.
    • Any symptoms of depression or anxiety. See the CKS topics on Depression, Generalized anxiety disorder, and Post-traumatic stress disorder for more information.
    • Any chronic conditions such as asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic kidney disease, and heart failure that may cause fatigue. See the CKS topics on Asthma, Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, Chronic kidney disease, and Heart failure - chronic for more information.
    • Any symptoms of post-exertional fatigue or malaise, cognitive difficulties or memory problems, sleep disturbance, and chronic pain that may suggest a diagnosis of chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).
      • Ask about any additional comorbid conditions that may be associated with CFS, such as migraine, irritable bowel syndrome, and fibromyalgia. See the CKS topics on Migraine and Irritable bowel syndrome for more information.
      • Be aware that CFS symptoms may fluctuate in severity and change over time.
      • See the section on Diagnosis of CFS for more information.
    • Any medication, including over-the-counter drugs, herbal remedies, and medicines purchased on the internet.
      • Tiredness may be caused by many drugs, including sedatives/hypnotics, antidepressants, muscle relaxants, opioids, antihypertensives, and antihistamines.
  • Assess for specific clinical features or red flags that may suggest a possible serious or life-threatening underlying condition:
    • Significant unintentional weight loss (5% of body weight over 6–12 months) may suggest malignancy, Addison's disease, diabetes mellitus, or hyperthyroidism. See the CKS topics on Addison's disease, Diabetes - type 1, and Hyperthyroidism for more information.
    • Fever, night sweats, or lymphadenopathy may suggest malignancy or infections, such as acute hepatitis, HIV, or active tuberculosis. See the CKS topics on HIV infection and AIDS, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, and Tuberculosis for more information.
    • Muscle or joint pain may suggest inflammatory joint disease or connective tissue disease. See the CKS topics on Giant cell arteritis, Polymyalgia rheumatica, and Rheumatoid arthritis for more information.
    • Localizing or focal neurological signs may suggest a neurodegenerative condition, such as brain tumour or multiple sclerosis. See the CKS topic on Brain and central nervous system cancers - recognition and referral for more information.
    • History of travel, insect or tick bites, and skin rash may suggest tropical infections or Lyme disease. See the CKS topic on Lyme disease for more information.
  • Examine the person, depending on the presenting clinical features, including a mental state examination to assess mood and cognitive functioning.
  • Consider whether investigations are needed to exclude an underlying cause, using clinical judgement.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment of tiredness are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guidelines Chronic fatigue syndrome/myalgic encephalomyelitis (or encephalopathy): diagnosis and management of CFS/ME in adults and children [NICE, 2007] and Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2017], a clinical cohort study of chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) symptom-based phenotypes [Collin, 2018], a population-based cross-sectional survey on fatigue [Galland-Decker, 2019], a cross-sectional study on the prevalence of CFS [Slomko, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles on tiredness [Rodriguez, 2000; Morrison, 2001; Rosenthal, 2008; Stadje, 2016], on investigating unexplained fatigue [Bansal, 2016], and on CFS [Fukuda, 1994].

Clinical features on history taking

  • The recommendation to clarify what the person means by tiredness/fatigue is based on expert opinion in review articles [Morrison, 2001; Rosenthal, 2008].
  • Expert opinion in a review article notes the importance of taking a full history when assessing a person with unexplained persistent fatigue [Bansal, 2016].
  • Expert opinion in review articles notes the importance of assessing the nature, impact, and duration of fatigue [Fukuda, 1994; Rodriguez, 2000].
  • The recommendation on taking a sleep history is based on a population-based survey on fatigue [Galland-Decker, 2019] and expert opinion in review articles [Rodriguez, 2000; Morrison, 2001; Rosenthal, 2008].
  • The recommendation on asking about lifestyle and psychosocial factors is based on the fact that fatigue is often associated with psychosocial stress, and may be caused by depression. A systematic review on the differential diagnosis of tiredness stresses the importance of assessing a person's mental health and psychosocial wellbeing [Stadje, 2016].
    • This is supported by expert opinion in a review article that states that a psychosocial history should include asking about depression and anxiety, alcohol or other substance misuse, and medication use [Fukuda, 1994].
    • Expert opinion in a review article notes that anxiety and depression can cause fatigue themselves, but acknowledges that these conditions can also complicate CFS, particularly if symptoms remain unexplained, there is unpredictability of relapses, and there is no improvement in symptoms. Expert opinion stresses the early detection and appropriate treatment of depression is important [Bansal, 2016].
  • The recommendation to ask about chronic conditions that may cause fatigue is based on different studies in the literature that found associations with multiple possible comorbidities.
    • A systematic review of 26 studies investigating the differential diagnosis of tiredness in primary care found that depression was the most common cause (seen in 18.5% of people), with other causes such as anaemia (2.8%) and malignancy (0.6%) being less common. A diagnosis of CFS was identified in 2% of cases. The authors noted variations in the definition of tiredness, study populations, and methodologies. It suggests a low positive-predictive value for the likelihood of malignancy in people with tiredness in primary care, especially for people presenting with tiredness as an isolated symptom, and notes that serious underlying disease is rare [Stadje, 2016].
    • A population-based cross-sectional survey (n = 2848) found that obesity, insomnia and sleep disturbance, depression, anaemia, and low self-rated health status were positively associated with fatigue, and recommended that these conditions should be part of an assessment of fatigue. The study did not, however, distinguish between physical and mental fatigue in its fatigue assessment tool [Galland-Decker, 2019].
    • A cross-sectional study in Poland of people presenting with self-reported fatigue (n = 1400) found that 93% had an associated chronic condition, including neurological, neurodegenerative, psychiatric, and immunological disorders [Slomko, 2019].
  • The information on possible symptoms suggesting CFS is based on the NICE clinical guideline, which notes that symptoms may fluctuate in severity and change over time [NICE, 2007].
  • The recommendation to ask about comorbid conditions that may be associated with CFS is based on a cohort study exploring different symptom-based phenotypes in people attending specialist CFS clinics [Collin, 2018].
    • People presenting with a polysymptomatic phenotype were more likely to have comorbid migraine, irritable bowel syndrome, depression, and anxiety compared with people with a oligosymptomatic (few symptoms) phenotype.
  • The recommendation to assess for medication that may be a cause of fatigue is based on expert opinion in review articles [Rodriguez, 2000; Morrison, 2001], and [Rosenthal, 2008].

Assessing for red flags

  • The information on red flags to assess for is largely based on the NICE clinical guidelines on CFS [NICE, 2007] and on suspected cancer [NICE, 2017]. It is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.

Clinical features on examination

  • The recommendation on performing an appropriate physical and mental state examination is extrapolated from the NICE clinical guideline on CFS [NICE, 2007] and is based on expert opinion in review articles [Fukuda, 1994; Bansal, 2016].
